The game is also becoming longer, with many matches lasting several hours. Another important factor is the use of computers in chess. These days, players can access vast databases of games and analyze their opponents' strategies. This has made it harder for older players to compete with younger ones. The world's top 10 players are all under 30 years old, and many are supported by large teams of assistants who help them prepare for matches.

Fischer's match with Spassky will be a test of his skills, but it's not just about winning or losing. The prize money is significant, and both players will earn millions regardless of the outcome. Volunteer tourism: a complex issue

Four experts discuss the pros and cons of international volunteering. Some argue that the actual impact of volunteering on development is limited. Volunteers often pay a fee to participate, which could be used to fund more effective local projects. This raises questions about the motivations behind volunteering, particularly for gap year travelers who may be seeking personal benefits rather than genuinely helping others.

On the other hand, volunteering can have positive effects. It can promote international understanding, conflict resolution, and global citizenship. It can also create networks and connections between people from different countries. However, if volunteering is only accessible to those from wealthy countries, it may perpetuate existing inequalities.

Volunteering can also be problematic. It can be seen as a form of imperialist charity, where wealthy individuals try to impose their values and ideas on others. Alternatively, it can be a way for individuals to gain skills and experience for their own careers. At its best, volunteering can provide a space for mutual learning and exchange between volunteers and local communities.

Some argue that volunteer tourism fits with the trend of individualized, non-political approaches to development. While this may seem positive, it can also avoid addressing the root causes of poverty and inequality. A more critical approach to volunteer tourism is needed, one that recognizes the complexities of global inequalities and the need for systemic change.

Many people listen to the radio in the morning to wake up. To make it easier to get out of bed, we use a clock radio. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, consisting of myself, Tom Granger, and Paul Bridges, tested five different models. We looked at their features and functions to see which one was the best.

One model had a "dual alarm function" that allowed you to set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. However, this function didn't work as expected. The instruction booklet suggested using it to set two different wake-up times, but most people's lives are not that organized. This model was more expensive than another one we tested, but it had a cassette player, which was a nice feature. You could fall asleep listening to your favorite music and wake up to a quiet morning.

We all liked the radio quality, but the clock radio was quite large. Paul Bridges said he needed space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone, and he was worried that the alarm might not go off. This model was the overall winner, and Paul Bridges said he was in love with it. The digital display was easy to read, and the snooze button was convenient.

However, some of us found it difficult to set up the clock radio. Tom Granger said the instructions were confusing, and he had to read them twice to get it working. The clock had a self-back-up feature, which was useful in case the power went out. But setting it up was a bit of a challenge.

We also tested a model with a built-in lamp, which was a nice feature. However, the lamp was hard to position, and it only shone on the clock, which was already illuminated. Tom Granger said the lamp was tacky and didn't work well. Paul Bridges liked the idea of the lamp, but he found the radio hard to tune.

Another model was the simplest and cheapest of the five. Tom Granger liked it because it was easy to set up and took up little space. It had old-fashioned dial tuning, which he preferred because it was more intuitive. The radio quality was good, and the buzzer worked well.

Overall, we tested five different clock radios and found that each had its pros and cons. We recommended the first model, which had the best features and was easy to use.<|eot_id|>

I still remember the day I met Picasso, the famous artist, when I was 18 years old. I was traveling around Europe and Morocco in a old van, trying to make a living by painting boats on the waterfront. One day, I saw Picasso eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes harbour. He was an 80-year-old man, but he was still very recognizable. I was lucky to have my sketchbook with me, and I decided to approach him and ask for his signature. To my surprise, he agreed, and he even added a beautiful drawing on the page.

I was thrilled and started a conversation with him, but it was difficult because his English was limited. An American woman at the table acted as our translator. She kept calling him the Maestro, and I told him about my passion for art and my admiration for his work. After a while, my friend suggested I go back and draw his portrait. I was hesitant at first, but he encouraged me to do it.

So, I went back to Picasso's table and asked if I could draw him. He agreed, and he started acting out different expressions, making it difficult for me to draw him. He rolled his eyes, stuck out his tongue, and made funny faces. I was tempted to give up, but he seemed to be testing my persistence. Finally, he relaxed and let me study him for a few minutes. I was struck by his youthful appearance, his dark eyes, and his athletic build. He seemed to be a private person, even though he was surrounded by people.

When the American woman told me that the Maestro wanted to see my drawing, I was embarrassed, but he insisted on seeing it. He gave my drawing a nod of approval and then drew a portrait of me himself. His drawing was much better than mine, and he added a few quick strokes to capture my smile and my nose. I was amazed by his talent and his generosity. In the end, he signed my drawing, and I felt grateful for the experience.

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a C1 level learner:

Have you ever walked into a store and left with more than you intended to buy? Many stores use clever tricks to make you spend more money. Here are some of the ways they do it:

A. Fresh and appealing

Supermarkets know that people love fresh food. They often put fresh fruit and vegetables near the entrance or display them in a beautiful way. They may also have a bakery that smells delicious, making you want to buy more. The store's color scheme can also influence your mood - for example, green is often used because it reminds people of fresh produce.

B. Displaying products effectively

The way products are displayed in a store can greatly affect how well they sell. Supermarkets use computers to track which areas of the store are most popular and place their most profitable products there. They also use special displays and promotions to attract customers.

C. Placing staples strategically

Supermarkets often place everyday items like bread, tea, and sugar in hard-to-reach areas of the store. This means you have to pass by more expensive items to get to them. Chain stores may also place their most popular products in less accessible areas, hoping you'll buy other things along the way.

D. Making products look exclusive

Some stores use special displays to make their products look exclusive. For example, fashion stores may display limited quantities of clothing to make it seem like the items are rare. This can make customers feel like they're getting a special deal.

E. Tempting totals

Supermarkets know that people are more likely to buy more if they can see the total cost of their shopping at the end. They often mix low-priced and high-priced items to keep you interested. Some stores may even sell certain items at a loss to get you to come in and buy more.

F. The importance of pricing

When shopping at chain stores, you may notice that prices are more important. Stores may use special pricing to make certain items seem more appealing. This can also help prevent theft by employees.

G. Lighting

Stores use lighting to create a welcoming atmosphere. Supermarkets may use special lighting to make food look more appealing, while chain stores may use natural light to show off clothing colors.

H. Guiding shoppers

Some stores use different carpeting to guide customers through the store. This can encourage you to follow a certain path and visit different areas of the store.

I. In-store promotions

Supermarkets use big pictures and advertisements to make you want to buy more. Some stores even have special screens on shopping carts that show you ads as you shop. This can increase sales by up to 30%.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

Apples have been around for thousands of years, and they come in many different shapes, sizes, and colors. However, in the late 20th century, the world was in danger of losing its apple heritage. 

Prehistoric humans started eating apples around 8,000 BC. They took apple seeds with them when they migrated to new areas, and they even dried apple halves for winter storage. These early apples were small and not like the apples we know today.

In the 1st century AD, the Romans brought new fruit-growing skills to Europe. They introduced the dessert apple, which became popular in Britain. Over time, British monks developed new apple varieties, and these are the ancestors of most modern apples.

In the 13th century, several types of apples became popular in Britain. One of the most famous was the Old English Pearmain, which was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Another popular apple was the Costard, which was sold in markets and gave us the word "costermonger."

In the 16th century, Henry VIII ordered his chief fruit supplier to visit France and learn about apple cultivation. This led to the development of new apple varieties, including the famous Pippins.

As apples became more popular, settlers took them with them when they traveled to new countries, such as Canada, Australia, and the United States. In North America, John Chapman, also known as "Johnny Appleseed," planted apple seeds and nurseries across the country.

In the 19th century, a Quaker farmer in Iowa discovered a new apple variety, which he named "Delicious." This apple became one of the most widely grown in the world. Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith, who worked as a midwife and maintained a farm and orchard.

Today, apples are grown all over the world, but many varieties have been lost due to commercialization and a focus on a few popular types. However, consumers are starting to demand more variety, and it is important to protect and value natural diversity in apples and other foods.

I finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000-meter race and was invited by the national team coach. Training at high altitude increases the production of red blood cells, which improves oxygen-carrying capacity. This has been proven by the success of generations of Kenyan runners.

My first African race was also a historic event, as it was the first-ever international cross-country race held on African soil. Although I finished behind 38 Kenyan runners, I felt I had a good race. Kenyan runners are known for their simple and uncomplicated approach to running, as well as their love for competing.

However, the key to their success is not just the altitude. I stayed with the Kenyan runners at their team training camp, where I learned about their training routine. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet above sea level, surrounded by beautiful fields and dense vegetation. The athletes live in simple dormitories and have a strict training schedule, with three workouts per day.

The day starts at 6 am with a leisurely run, followed by interval training and a steady run in the afternoon. The total distance covered each day is around 40 kilometers. On Sundays, they have a shorter run of 20 kilometers. Life at the camp is uncomplicated, with a simple breakfast, lunch, and dinner menu. After training, they take a bath in one of the nearby streams.

By the time I left the camp, I had a new appreciation for Kenyan success. It's not just genetics, upbringing, or altitude that contributes to their success. I believe it's the purity and simplicity of their lifestyle, their grueling workouts, and their passion for success that make them the best distance runners in the world.

Advertising is struggling. It's not just the economic downturn. Advertising has been declining since 1989, even before the recession started. The problem is that advertisers are not adapting to the changing market. They still think in terms of mass markets and mass media, but with so many brands and media options, target audiences have become smaller and more fragmented. Even big brands rarely target specific minority groups.

Think about your own shopping habits. You might buy 30-50 items at a supermarket, but most of them won't be advertised brands. You might only buy a few hundred brands in a year, and even fewer will be advertised brands. In fact, you're unlikely to buy more than 400 different brands in a year. Yet, there are over 32,000 branded goods and services being advertised. This means that most advertising is wasted, as you're not likely to buy most of the products being advertised.

When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about 1 in 16, which means 94% of commercials are wasted. You might think you're immune to advertising, but you're not. The truth is, nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised. People only register a small number of ads and ignore the rest.

Advertising can be effective, but it's expensive and often wasteful. To make it more effective, advertisers need to target specific groups more precisely. They can't know in advance who will respond to their ads, so they have to reach a large number of people to reach the right minority. This is one of the main differences between advertising and face-to-face sales. Even the most targeted direct mail campaigns can't achieve a 100% response rate.

To make advertising more effective, advertisers need to focus on targeting specific groups more precisely. They need to stop wasting money on advertising to people who won't respond. Any campaign that can win over 2% of the population would be considered successful. The most effective way to reach these people may be through mass media, but advertisers need to adapt to the changing market and target their message more precisely.<|eot_id|>

Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of Sherlock Holmes, was known for being a rational person. However, in 1920, he was convinced that photographs of fairies taken in a garden were real. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The photos are still beautiful, but the trick shows that the camera is not always honest. In fact, photographers have always been able to manipulate their images. Today, with computer software, we can easily edit our digital photos. It's a myth that photography was once completely honest. From the very beginning, photographers have been able to change the way things look in their pictures.

Margaret Wilkins has a special ability to find water. She uses a forked hazel rod to detect water underground. Many farmers whose wells have dried up hire her services. She works with her husband, who uses modern technology to drill wells. But when it comes to finding water, Margaret relies on her "sixth sense". 

Dowsing, the ability to locate water, minerals, and lost objects, is a mysterious skill. There are many theories about how it works, from physical forces like magnetism to spiritual explanations. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and dowsers can sense these vibrations. Some dowsers claim they can "feel" or "smell" water.

The Wilkins have been very busy during the recent drought. They have a long waiting list of customers, mostly farmers with dry wells. They also work with people who own remote cottages or holiday homes where it's expensive to run water pipes. Margaret tries to find water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She looks for areas where the water is likely to be clean and safe.

To start, Margaret uses a map and a pendulum to locate likely areas. Then, she walks over the fields with her forked hazel stick. When she's above water, she gets a strange feeling, and the stick rises up. Her husband also dowses the area, and they usually agree on the exact spot to drill. If they don't agree, they won't drill and will keep searching until they do.

Margaret's ability to find water is not unique. Anthropologists and writers have studied this mysterious skill for a long time. Margaret calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment", which is the closest explanation we have for why she's so accurate. **The Careers of Five Women**

Meet five women who work in different professions. They share their experiences, highlighting the good and the challenging parts of their jobs.

**The Brain Surgeon**

Anne, a 34-year-old brain surgeon, starts her day at 6:30 am. She goes to the gym, then gets to work at 8 am and begins operating at 8:30 am. She works long hours, sometimes up to 10 hours straight, without breaks. Deciding which operations to perform and managing her time can be stressful. However, she finds it rewarding when patients recover well. She spends some time explaining operations to patients and comforting those who are anxious. Anne often works late and worries about her work even on her days off.

**The Senior Designer**

Marita, a 31-year-old senior designer, starts her day at 7:45 am. She meets with her team at 10:30 am to discuss projects and any issues. Her work involves designing and producing materials, such as brochures and advertisements. She spends a lot of time communicating with clients and team members. Deadlines can be tight, and Marita often works long hours, including evenings and weekends. She finds it difficult to unwind after a busy day.

**The Chauffeur**

Linda, a 42-year-old chauffeur, starts her day at 7 am or 4:30 am, depending on her schedule. She drives clients to their destinations, often recommending restaurants and shops along the way. She has to be careful to stay focused on the road and avoid distractions. Linda works long hours, up to 15 hours a day, and has to be mindful of her physical and mental well-being.

**The Landscape Gardener**

Tracy, a 27-year-old landscape gardener, starts her day at 7:30 am. She and her assistant maintain and design gardens for private clients. They work long hours, sometimes until 10 pm in the summer. Tracy enjoys using old materials and unique plants to create beautiful gardens. However, she finds it challenging when clients have unrealistic expectations. She often works evenings and weekends to respond to client calls and messages.

**The Civil Engineer**

Zena, a 27-year-old civil engineer, starts her day at 8:30 am at a construction site. She oversees the building of bridges and a retaining wall. Her tasks include checking the work of contractors and ensuring they follow safety guidelines. Zena often works long hours and is on call 24/7. **Getting Ahead at Work: The Power of Leadership**

A good leader is someone who inspires others, brings about change, and shows the way forward. Leadership is not about physical characteristics like height or intelligence. It's about making things happen through people who share your enthusiasm and passion. A good leader should be able to express themselves clearly and confidently.

According to Pat Dixon, author of "Making the Difference," leadership is about having the confidence to say "I believe" instead of "I think." This confidence is essential for conveying enthusiasm and encouraging others to share your vision.

John van Maurik, director of a leadership course, believes that everyone has the potential to be a leader. It's about recognizing and developing your natural talents and using them effectively.

In our daily work, we may not always recognize leadership qualities in ourselves or others. However, effective leadership is crucial for success in any organization. A good leader motivates and supports their team members, whereas a poor leader can make them feel unimportant and unvalued.

Managers and leaders are not the same thing. Managers focus on following established procedures, while leaders create their own path. A good leader can transform an organization, whereas a good manager can only maintain the status quo.

Whether you're a manager or an employee, improving your leadership skills can benefit you. Here are some tips:

* Identify your passions and convictions and take action on them.
* Recognize your ability to lead and use it to your advantage.
* Be willing to take risks and learn from your mistakes.
* Develop your communication skills and be open to feedback.
* Set goals and work towards them, and be willing to delegate and motivate others.
* Don't assume that your leadership style will always be successful; be willing to adapt and learn from others.

Remember, leadership is not something that happens overnight. It requires effort, practice, and patience. By developing your leadership skills, you can enhance your effectiveness and career prospects.<|eot_id|>

E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

This classic western has been re-released on video and showcases director Leone's craftsmanship. The sound editing is particularly impressive, and the music is iconic. The story is brutal and intense, and the characters are morally ambiguous.

F. The Longest Day

This epic war film features an all-star cast and four directors. While the film is impressive in terms of logistics, it feels overly long and would be better suited to the big screen. The video release is a diminished experience compared to seeing it in a theater.

BOOK B Curtains for the Cardinal starts with a dramatic event and follows Sigismondo, a troubleshooter for the Italian aristocracy, as he becomes involved in a complex web of politics, intrigue, and murder. Although the book is a bit long, it's still an exciting read.

BOOK C File Under: Deceased introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, a tax inspector who finds herself investigating a murder. Despite facing challenges and disapproval, Leah is a strong and capable character. This is a refreshing change from traditional detectives.

BOOK D Double Deuce by Robert B. Parker features his famous detective, Spenser, who helps his friend Hawk to clean up a troubled neighborhood in Boston. The book has fast-paced dialogue and a mix of action and philosophy.

BOOK E False Prophet by Faye Kellermann follows detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn as they investigate a burglary at the home of a famous actress's daughter. The author's writing style makes this an engaging mystery.

BOOK F Blood Red, Snow White by Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock is a suspense novel about a lawyer who defends a woman accused of a crime. The story is full of romance, money, and violence, making it an engrossing read.

BOOK G Dead for a Ducat by Simon Shaw is a comedy about an actor who is supposed to play Robin Hood, but things don't go as planned. The book has a cast of colorful characters, but the story is not as strong as some of Shaw's other works.

BOOK H Fall Down Easy by Lawrence Gough is a detective novel about a bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow build-up of tension and the portrayal of the clever robber make this a standout novel in the genre.

This summer, I quit my job and plan to rent out my flat and travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 and nervous. I've traveled before, but I've been stuck in a routine and haven't felt fulfilled. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. I now have no responsibilities, and many of my friends are envious of my freedom.

I'm nervous because I'm not sure if I can adjust to a more basic way of life. I've been used to a certain standard of living, and I worry about feeling out of place among younger backpackers. However, I'm not alone. Many Britons in their 20s and 30s are realizing that adventure is within reach. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet, says that people are becoming aware that they can have the opportunity to travel whenever they want, as long as they're brave and organized.

For some, traveling is a chance to have one last adventure before settling down. Danny and Tammy, a couple in their 20s, are taking a year-long trip around the world. For others, like Matt, who left the army, traveling was a way to break free from a rigid routine. There are many reasons why people in their 30s are traveling, but there are common factors. More people are working on short-term contracts, and companies are even offering career breaks.

For Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, an increasing number of thirty-somethings are taking stock of their lives. He believes that people are no longer afraid to ask themselves if they're happy with their lives and are willing to take a chance to reassess and find a more balanced life. Is traveling just a sign of our generation's inability to grow up? Jennifer Cox doesn't think so. She believes it's a sign of a more educated and stable society that values living a balanced life.

I'm excited about my upcoming trip, but I'm also a bit apprehensive about leaving behind my comfortable routine. I'm not sure if I'd be doing this if I hadn't found my boss so unbearable. For me, this trip is about grabbing life by the horns and taking a chance. Whatever the outcome, I'll be proud of myself for taking the leap.<|eot_id|>

Some parts of the museum are already impressive, such as the panoramic views of Edinburgh Castle and the sequence of spaces that open into each other. Here is a rewritten version of the passage at a level suitable for C1 learners:

"The end of print newspapers may not be imminent. The idea of transition is often met with fear and uncertainty, but it can also be a gradual and natural process. However, the shift of newspapers to the online world is a different story. This process is uncertain and challenging because it may not be a smooth transition at all.

Despite the decline in print newspaper sales, online visits to the same papers' websites are increasing. The latest figures show that The Daily Telegraph, The Guardian, and many other newspapers have seen a decline in print circulation, but their online readership is growing. However, this trend is not uniform and may be influenced by various factors such as timing, demographics, and geography.

Some experts argue that the crisis in the newspaper industry is mainly affecting print newspapers, while others claim that online newspapers are the future. However, the latest survey by the World Association of Newspapers shows that global circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, with sales in Asia making up for the decline in the West.

The situation is similar in the magazine industry, where news and current affairs magazines have seen a 5.4% increase in sales. In the book industry, e-readers are popular, but sales of physical books have not declined significantly.

The idea that young people are abandoning newspaper-reading is exaggerated. According to the latest National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15-35 still follow the main national dailies. Different countries have different trends, with some experiencing a significant decline in print circulation, while others have seen a smaller decline or even an increase.

The varying national trends suggest that the situation is more complex than the proponents of the digital revolution assume. The assumption that online advertising revenues would pay for the transition and make online newspapers successful has not come true. Many US newspapers have built paywalls around their products, but the best way to attract paying readers is to offer a joint package of print and digital access.

Print is still an important tool in selling internet subscriptions, and its advertising rates are significantly higher than online rates. However, maintaining both an active website and an active print edition is challenging, complex, and expensive. Newspaper brands still have a strong presence in print, but online, it is harder to be noticed."

Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

**Photographing People**

People are the most interesting subjects in photography. A picture with someone in it is often more engaging than the same shot without a person. However, photographing people can be challenging. The photographer must consider not only technical and artistic aspects but also the subject's actions, gestures, and expressions. The presence of the camera can sometimes have a negative effect on these.

**Group Shots**

When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances, or have some sit or kneel in front to make it easier to see everyone's faces.

**Posing for Pictures**

People often stiffen up when taking pictures. Help your subject relax by suggesting a comfortable position, such as folding their arms or putting them in their pockets.

**Approaching the Subject**

Don't pretend you're not taking a picture when it's clear you are. Most people will agree to be photographed and are flattered by it. However, they may become self-conscious, so you may need to direct them.

**Eye Contact**

A picture gains impact when the subject looks directly at the camera. Ask your subject to look into the lens, but not necessarily smile. You may need to remind them to look at the camera just before taking the shot.

**Candid Concentration**

An alternative to direct eye contact is for the subject to focus on something within the picture area. This can be easier for them and create a sense of observation.

**Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures can tell us more about the subject than anything else. Look for familiar expressions like smiles, winks, or tears to add emotional depth to your photos.

**Situational Interest**

The subject's background or environment can add interest and information to the picture. Try to exclude irrelevant details and blur them if necessary. Make sure the subject is not overwhelmed by the background.

**Interaction**

When photographing multiple people, look for moments of interaction, such as eye contact, physical contact, or reactions to each other.

**People and Places**

When taking pictures of people in a new location, use a standard or wide-angle lens and move back to capture the whole scene. Ask your subjects to come close to the camera and compose the picture so that they form a foreground interest without obscuring the background.

**To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Decide why you're taking the picture. If it's to remember someone, a posed picture might be suitable. However, candid shots of events as they happen are often more engaging and memorable.

I minimized changes to the factual content while simplifying the language and sentence structure to make it more accessible to a C1 learner. I also removed some technical terms and jargon to make the text more readable.<|eot_id|>

Emotional Intelligence: The Key to Success

The way we work is changing. We're no longer judged solely on our intelligence, skills, and experience. Instead, we're being evaluated on how well we work with others and manage our own emotions. This new standard is crucial for getting hired, advancing in our careers, and even staying relevant in the job market. 

Emotional intelligence is about being able to understand and manage our own emotions, as well as those of others. It involves skills like empathy, initiative, adaptability, and persuasiveness. In today's workplace, where job security is uncertain and jobs are constantly changing, emotional intelligence is becoming increasingly important.

Businesses are recognizing the value of emotional intelligence and are incorporating it into their management strategies. In fact, companies that prioritize emotional intelligence tend to perform better and have a competitive edge. Emotional intelligence is not just about being nice or being good at emotional manipulation. It's about being able to manage our emotions and those of others in a way that helps us work together effectively towards a common goal.

The good news is that emotional intelligence can be developed and improved over time. In fact, research shows that people tend to become more emotionally intelligent as they gain experience and mature. This means that we can all work on developing our emotional intelligence and adding it to our toolkit for success.

While emotional intelligence is not a magic formula for success, it is a crucial component of being successful in today's fast-changing job market. Ignoring emotional intelligence can lead to poor performance and stagnation, but developing it can lead to greater success and stability.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

Acupuncture is a traditional Chinese medicine that has been used for over 2,000 years. It involves inserting fine needles into the skin to stimulate the body's energy, known as Qi. The goal is to restore balance to the body and relieve pain. Acupuncture is used to treat many conditions, but its effectiveness in relieving pain has been most studied and accepted by Western doctors.

The concept of Qi is central to traditional Chinese medicine. It is believed that Qi flows through the body along specific pathways, or meridians, and that an imbalance of Qi can lead to illness. During an acupuncture session, the practitioner will assess the patient's overall health, including their pulse, tongue, and physical condition, to identify areas of imbalance.

There are over 300 points on the body where acupuncture needles can be inserted. These points are related to the meridians and are not necessarily located near the area of pain. Patients often report a mild, tingling sensation when the needle is inserted, which indicates that the Qi has been stimulated.

While some Western doctors do not accept the concept of Qi, many have found that acupuncture can be effective in relieving pain. There are several theories about how acupuncture works, including the idea that it can block pain signals to the brain or release natural pain-relieving chemicals.

Acupuncture is commonly used to treat chronic pain, including back pain, arthritis, and headaches. It is also used to treat other types of pain, such as menstrual pain and pain associated with terminal illnesses. In recent years, acupuncture has been used as an alternative to anesthesia during surgery, with some patients reporting reduced pain and fewer side effects.

While the effectiveness of acupuncture is difficult to measure, many studies have shown that it can be effective for chronic pain relief, with success rates ranging from 50 to 80%. Acupuncturists typically recommend a series of sessions to achieve optimal results, and some patients may experience improvement after just a few visits.

Acupuncture is a holistic approach to pain management, taking into account not just the physical symptoms but also the patient's overall well-being and lifestyle. This approach can be quite different from Western medicine, which often focuses on specific symptoms and treatments. When choosing an acupuncturist, it is important to find one who is qualified and experienced, and to consult with a medical doctor if necessary.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. She is known for her clever and imaginative stories. At first, you might think she's a strict school principal because of her calm and serious appearance. But she's actually a shy person. She admits that her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is based on herself if she were a man. Like Dalgliesh, she prefers to work alone and needs quiet time to write. She can write anywhere as long as it's private.

P.D. James is a big fan of other writers, including her friend Ruth Rendell. She likes books by women writers like Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, as well as men like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh. She thinks they are great novelists.

P.D. James didn't become successful until later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel was published. She grew up in Oxford and Cambridge, where she met her husband. She had to work hard to support her family, but she didn't have time to write. Her husband was sick, and she had to take care of their two daughters.

P.D. James worked in administration for the National Health Service and the Home Office. She was good at organizing things and managed five psychiatric outpatients' clinics. She also worked in forensic science and the juvenile crime division. She became used to seeing dead bodies, but it wasn't the death itself that inspired her. She loved the way detective stories are structured and wanted to write one as a way to learn how to write a serious novel.

P.D. James says that writing detective stories is a way to bring order to chaos. Solving a crime shows that life is valuable, even if it's not always perfect. She believes that nobody likes violence.

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is gaining popularity. In some countries, employers ask for handwriting samples during job interviews. Handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is considered a legitimate science in many countries. Researchers believe it can be a useful tool to identify certain health issues, such as heart disease and cancer, and to understand a person's mental state and emotional well-being.

Many companies now employ graphologists to analyze the handwriting of potential employees for key positions. However, most doctors and psychiatrists remain skeptical about the value of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience, argues that they should take it more seriously. She believes that handwriting can reveal a person's psychological characteristics, medical conditions, and potential.

According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be particularly useful in identifying potential criminal tendencies. She claims that criminals often have distinctive handwriting, such as poor letter formation and repeated letters. Graphologists can also use handwriting to predict whether someone is honest, manipulative, or a reliable employee.

Ms. Marne suggests that handwriting can also reveal other psychological traits, such as emotional stability, sensitivity, and confidence. For example, people with handwriting that forms "threads" instead of individual letters are likely to be devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals may be trying to hide their true selves. Very light pressure on the pen can indicate sensitivity and a lack of vitality.

Ms. Marne emphasizes that becoming a skilled graphologist requires six years of study and experience, combined with empathy and intuition. She believes that more research is needed to establish graphology as a legitimate scientific discipline. Some psychiatrists are critical of graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic ability, and writing style, and has no other significance.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a C1 level learner:

A new survey suggests that a happy and healthy workforce is linked to fresh air and suitable chairs. We visited four offices to see how healthy and happy they were as working environments. Our expert panel consisted of a building health consultant, an ergonomist, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their assessments.

Office A: Advertising Agency

The building health consultant said that this office is very basic, with no central heating or ventilation, and windows that open directly onto the street. However, the employees, who are part of a small, dynamic team, seem to be happy. They adapt to the changing seasons by opening doors and windows or using electric radiators, just like they would at home. This might be the key: the team has created a cozy and homely working environment, without any bureaucracy imposed from outside.

The ergonomist noted that the furniture is varied and not very suitable for working comfortably. However, the employees have a varied schedule, which includes office work, client meetings, and presentations. This variety reduces the risk of fatigue, boredom, and physical problems.

The occupational psychologist found that the staff are delighted with the variety of work and the flexibility of the office space. They said that the office is "just the right size" - small enough to know what colleagues are doing, but large enough to focus on personal work. The office is both attractive and fun, conveying a sense of efficiency and creativity.

Office B: News Service

The building health consultant said that this office is comfortable and well-maintained, with good air quality and a no-smoking policy. The ergonomist praised the excellent chairs, good lighting, and computer equipment. However, the space could be improved by better layout and more visual stimulation.

The occupational psychologist noted that the office is impersonal and lacks visual interest, with bare walls and few decorations. Most staff have been there for at least five years, and relationships are satisfactory. The office could be improved by positioning desks to facilitate sharing of information and displaying success stories or project updates on the walls.

Office C: Bank

The building health consultant said that this office is mixed in terms of how people feel about it. The atmosphere is like being in a showcase, with many similar exhibits on display. Despite a mix of smokers and non-smokers in a small space, the air doesn't seem stale, even when someone is smoking nearby.

The ergonomist found the office to be uninspiring, with standard furniture that is barely adequate. Not all chairs are suitable for computer use, and some are user-chosen. Computer screens are often on small desk units with lowered keyboard shelves, which is no longer considered suitable for modern equipment.

The occupational psychologist noted that staff are supportive and well-equipped with technology. There are many communication awards on display, and the wood-colored paneling and brown carpet give a slightly somber atmosphere. The office is bustling with activity.

Office D: Newspaper

The building health consultant said that it's hard to find anything positive about this building. The air-conditioning is crude, resulting in large temperature variations. The space is cluttered, and most people have inadequate desk space. The office is dusty, with many places for dust to accumulate. The shed-like roof also collects dust, which falls on those sitting below when disturbed.

The ergonomist found the furniture to be unsuitable for a high-tech industry, with most chairs being of little value for keyboard users, especially those under 1.75 meters tall. Many chairs are old, lack adjustment, and have armrests that prevent users from getting close to the desk.

The occupational psychologist noted that the office is dirty, with old brown chairs, soiled carpets, and dust everywhere. There is a lot of room for improvement, including tidying up, recognizing individual success, improving air conditioning, and adopting a team-working policy. When we visited, few conversations were happening, and everyone seemed stressed and driven by deadlines.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text:

Chewing gum is a popular habit that has been around for thousands of years. Today, Americans alone chew 12 million sticks of gum every day. But have you ever wondered how this habit started? Let's take a journey through time and find out.

In ancient Greece, people chewed a type of gum made from the bark of the mastic tree. Women especially liked it because it helped keep their teeth clean and fresh. Later, American colonists adopted a similar habit, chewing resin that formed on spruce trees.

The modern chewing gum we know today has its roots in the 1860s, when people discovered a milky substance called chicle, which comes from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This new type of gum was smoother, more satisfying, and more elastic, and soon a whole industry was born.

However, cultivating sapodilla trees has been a challenge. Today, only a few people, called chicleros, still gather sapodilla, facing many dangers and difficulties. They trek through the rainforest, avoiding snakes, insects, and even a type of fly that lays its eggs in their ears and nose.

Despite these challenges, the demand for chicle has decreased, and manufacturers have turned to synthetic alternatives to reduce costs and meet demand. Meanwhile, gum producers are coming up with new and creative ways to market their products, claiming that gum can help with relaxation, energy, and even reduce tooth decay.

Research is also ongoing to develop new textures and flavors. Some flavors still use natural ingredients, while others are artificial. Interestingly, the United States has dedicated over 137 square kilometers to growing mint, which is used in the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

There was no one to greet them, and they had to use a buzzer to get in.

When they arrived at the reception, the staff couldn't find their booking. It turned out that many rooms were empty that night. Sue was not happy with the room she was shown, as it was stuffy and had a big hole in the wall. When she started her job, she was known for being tough, but she says she's not really tough. The next morning, she told the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, about her findings. He apologized for the unpleasant smell in the main lounge and promised to fix it.

Sue also suggested that the staff should be more careful when showing guests to their rooms. She praised two staff members, Emma and Trudy, for their good work. The hotel's food was also good, so it kept its two-rosette rating. Sue gave the hotel some advice on how to improve, including serving better desserts. It's Sue's job to tell hotels what they need to improve, even if it's hard. She has to write a report and give the hotel a verbal warning. Here is the simplified text, making it more accessible to a C1 level learner:

My journey to climb the Seven Summits, the highest peaks on each continent, began later in life. I'll share my experiences in the order I completed them.

A. Mount Everest, Asia (8,848m)
As we climbed, my partner, Dougal Haston, and I found ourselves in a snow cave 91m below the summit. I thought it was strange that only the two of us were there, and I started talking to my feet! The cold was getting into my toes, and I worried about frostbite. Over the next two days, I relived our time on the summit ridge. I realized that I couldn't have asked for a better climbing partner than Dougal. He inspired confidence in me, and I felt calm, knowing that everything would work out.

B. Mount McKinley, North America (6,194m)
In April 1976, Dougal and I arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days hauling equipment and food to the base. We decided to climb 'alpine style', carrying our gear and food with us. We followed a new route, which was challenging, and spent the third night on a windswept ridge. The air pressure in the polar regions is lower than expected, making it feel like we were at a higher altitude. We finally reached the summit and were relieved to be done.

C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)
In September 1976, Paul Braithwaite and I flew to Nairobi with plans to climb Mt. Kenya. We ended up climbing Kilimanjaro instead. We got lost in the dense jungle and had to find a rock pool for water. We attempted a direct start up the breach wall but retreated due to falling rock and ice. We took the Umbwe route to the surrealistic summit.

D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
In January 1992, I climbed Aconcagua with my wife, Sharu. We joined a guide and a party going up the Polish Glacier, away from the busy standard route. We had to wait out bad weather for three days before starting our climb. We decided to miss the glacier and take the standard route instead. The wind was strong, but we reached the summit and camped outside the refuge.

E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
In 1992, I learned that climbing Vinson Massif was a matter of guiding people to finance the trip. This made the Seven Summits a reality. Our team traveled to the South Pole, where the sun was always above the horizon. We left camp and headed to the summit, facing strong winds and temperatures below -50°C. We reached the top within 8 hours, but visibility was limited due to the storm.

F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
In 1994, our team assembled in St Petersburg and traveled to the settlement of Terskol. We took a cableway to 3,900m and then walked to the refuge at 4,200m. The wind was strong, and we had to cross open slopes and glassy ice. We reached the summit, but found another kilometer-long ridge to the actual summit. We returned to the refuge and descended the next day.

G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
In 1994, we climbed Carstensz Pyramid, hoping to establish a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. We were warned about potential dangers, but we proceeded, reaching the summit by 11 am. I received a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit, marking the completion of my Seven Summits journey.<|eot_id|>

end_header_id|>

We had lived in our valley for 16 months when we realized the dangers that could threaten our survival. The year was unusual, with early storms and heavy snowfall before November. We had felt safe and sheltered in our valley, protected by the surrounding hills. However, the snow was deeper on the nearby hills and stayed there for longer. The wind was strong, and we could feel the gusts, but the trees were still stable.

Although the snow and wind were inconvenient, they didn't cause us much trouble. Our main concern was the river, the Ryburn, which normally flowed gently. We remembered that if the dams hadn't been built, the river could have caused problems. The snow started to melt, and we watched as the clouds grew thicker and darker, warning us of what was to come. The river began to rise, and we worried about the dam, which was almost at its maximum capacity.

Finally, the dam overflowed, and the water poured down the stream, making it much deeper than usual. We were relieved when the water level dropped, and the dam held. We had seen similar floods in the past, but now the dam prevents the river from overflowing and causing damage. We can enjoy the powerful river and the clouds that bring rain, knowing that our home is safe and secure.

Here is a simplified version of the text, suitable for a C1 learner:

As a film critic for The Front Page, I look back on the last ten years of my work. Writing for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I did some reviewing for other newspapers, magazines, and radio. I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but Tom wasn't a journalist by profession. Initially, his idea was to have a team of critics cover various art forms, including books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would meet weekly to discuss our assignments, and there would be guests to make the atmosphere more social. It was a dream come true to be part of a new newspaper. However, the team concept didn't work out as planned. We ended up working individually, mostly by phone. The public preferred to associate a reviewer with a specific area, so I focused on film. Without Tom's initial push, I wouldn't have developed my current approach, which involves writing an extended review of one film each week. I prefer this arrangement, as it allows me to explore my ideas more deeply. I wouldn't be interested in reviewing every film that comes out, as that would become too routine. Instead, I can make the most of my space to develop my arguments, even on less exciting weeks. So, what is my role in the public sphere? I assume people choose which films to see based on the stars, publicity, or director. Loyalty to a particular genre or type of film can also play a role. It's rare for someone who dislikes westerns to attend one after reading a review, or for a romantic film fan to avoid a love story because of a negative review. So, if a film review isn't a consumer guide, what is its purpose? I don't feel responsible for being "right" about a movie, nor do I think there should be a certain number of "great" and "bad" films each year. My task is to present a well-reasoned argument. I'm not a judge, and I wouldn't want to be.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

I'm Amanda Roy, and I love collecting things. Many people share this passion, and one in three adults collects something. Collecting is a world of passion, excitement, and joy. However, remember that if you don't fall in love with an object, don't collect it.

People have been collecting things for centuries. In the past, people collected pebbles and seashells because of their beauty. Today, children still collect stones and shells for the same reason. I've been collecting things my whole life. I've collected flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was of stones I found in my parents' garden.

I was lucky to go to a school in a remote part of England, where I would visit a local museum with my parents. I was fascinated by the objects on display. Many people collect things, and the reasons why are interesting. Some people collect because it's the only part of their life where they have complete control. For me, collecting is just something I enjoy.

There are many famous collectors throughout history. The Duc de Berry in France had a collection of natural and artificial curiosities. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. However, you don't have to be rich or powerful to start a collection. I've collected things like tulip bulbs and china cups, searching for unique examples with great enthusiasm.

I once collected American rag dolls, 350 of them. I searched all over the USA for these dolls, and it was exciting to find each new variation. Unfortunately, my collection was destroyed in a house fire. It was sad to see my collection go, but it's the way collections change hands that fascinates me. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet can give value to an object. As certain objects become popular, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now valuable if you still have the original boxes. (Unfortunately, I threw away mine, along with the contents.)

I also work with schools and training centers, running courses for people who make decisions about the ocean. I take them on boat trips to help them understand the importance of marine conservation. It's a rewarding job, but it can be challenging because I work for a charity and need to find more funding.

Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher

We found Glencorn Lodge through an advertisement in a newspaper. We had a bad experience at a hotel the previous summer because the food was terrible. We've been playing cards together since we were young, and we've been going to Glencorn Lodge every year since then.

When we arrived, Mrs. Malseed, the owner, was already waiting for us in the large hall, which always smells of flowers. She has a knack for knowing when guests are about to arrive. She showed us to our rooms, which are named after flowers. In the winter, when it's quiet, she takes care of the little details, like painting flower names on the doors. Her husband, Mr. Malseed, is in charge of redecorating and repairs.

We were warmly welcomed by Mr. Malseed, who said, "A hundred thousand welcomes!" in the Irish way. He has a warm smile and twinkling eyes, making us feel like more than just hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and we knew our holiday had begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn Lodge; everything was as we had expected.

After dinner, we played cards for a bit, but not for too long because we were still tired from the journey. There were other people in the lounge, including a man on his own and a French couple. In the morning, we would usually take a walk along the beach, have coffee in the nearby village, and then come back for lunch. In the afternoon, we would go on a drive. This is our usual routine, which we've developed over the years.

I fell in love with the beautiful landscape of Ireland the first time I came here, and I know the others did too.<|eot_id|>

Are you unhappy in your job but unsure how to change? Many people find that talking to a careers advisor helps. You'll be asked to write a brief autobiography and take a series of tests called "psychometrics". The results will give you a summary and suggest new career paths, along with any necessary retraining.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a large organization that offers career guidance. The test was like a school exam, but it wasn't about passing or failing. The questions were designed to help the advisor understand me better. I was surprised to find that I didn't do well in the scientific, technical, and practical sections, but I was relieved to learn that I had made the right decision in pursuing journalism.

Changing your career doesn't always mean making a drastic change. Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years and turned to Career Analysts for help. She was surprised to discover she had a talent for design, but ultimately decided to use her existing skills to move into public relations.

Career guidance can be helpful for people who are unsure about their career direction. Juliet Greene, 26, visited Career Counselling Services and took the tests, which showed her interest in sciences. After four sessions with an advisor, she decided to pursue a degree in geology.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a C1 learner:

Chocolate is a big business today, with people spending over £230 million on it in the UK at Easter. This is 8% of all chocolate sold worldwide. Although chocolate is now widely available, its origins date back over 3,000 years to the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilisations in Central America. The cacao tree, which is native to Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia, produces fruit with 20-40 seeds that can be used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, these seeds are often called cocoa beans, although this is a misspelling from the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as currency and to make a bitter drink called xocoatl. This drink was flavoured with spices and used on special occasions. The Spanish found it more palatable with cinnamon and sugar, but it didn't become popular in Europe until the 17th century. Chocolate houses were set up in European cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate.

In the 19th century, chocolate powder was invented, making it easier to make chocolate at home. The chocolate bar as we know it today was first produced in 1847 by a British company. Milk chocolate was introduced later, and the British market was dominated by French companies until Cadbury introduced its famous Dairy Milk bar in 1905. Today, chocolate intake in the UK has stabilised, and manufacturers are looking for new ways to attract customers. Some are now offering chocolate in different forms, such as ice cream or soft drinks.

At the same time, cacao farmers are still feeling the effects of a crash in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers were forced out of business. As you enjoy your next chocolate bar, spare a thought for these farmers who work hard to produce the chocolate we love.

Terence and Chris Madden, a father-son team, have traveled from Canada to Wales in search of gold. They believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could contain up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After 10 years of digging, they are close to finding a vein of gold worth millions of dollars.

"We're finding high levels of gold as we dig," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool. "We just need to get a few more meters to where it's concentrated." The pair have dedicated their lives to searching for gold. They started their search after Terence read about pockets of gold in the Dolgellau gold belt, an area around the Welsh town of Dolgellau.

The father and son team have spent the past 10 years clearing the land, taking samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They have dug out 150 tons of rock to form a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they need £50,000 to lower the mine a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says they are not sure if they will find a backer.

The news of the dig has attracted attention from locals and tourists. The town of Dolgellau relies on tourism, and residents are cautiously hopeful. "It would be great for the town if they find gold," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel. "But we don't want people to start digging randomly."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since its peak in the late 1880s, when many mines operated in the area. One of the last remaining mines closed recently. However, individual gold-diggers are returning to the area, hoping to strike it rich. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge. When she's not teaching, Rachel goes on underwater adventures. She uses a special vehicle that's like a small car, and it takes her three kilometers down to the ocean floor. The space inside is very small, so she can almost touch the two pilots who accompany her. They have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside.

A dive can take up to 16 hours. The first three hours are spent going down to the ocean floor, then they collect samples of rock and water for ten hours, and finally, they head back up to the surface in three hours. If anything goes wrong, Rachel can hit a panic button, and a small escape vessel will be released, which will quickly take her to the surface.

Rachel has made six dives so far. Last year, she went on a dive with a Russian team to a site near the Canary Islands. They explored an area with many underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This "black smoke" is actually hot water that pours out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.

Rachel has also been on a dive with an American team. During that dive, there was an explosion, and Rachel thought she was going to die. But luckily, they were okay, and they were relieved to be alive.

Rachel loves her job because it's an adventure. Every time she looks out of the window of her underwater vehicle and sees the volcanoes, she feels a sense of wonder. She's one of the few people who have ever seen these underwater wonders, and it's an incredible feeling.

Losing your luggage when traveling can be frustrating. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your bag. This can be especially problematic if you're traveling to a different climate or far from home. Although airlines don't usually reveal how often they lose luggage, it's a common issue for frequent travelers. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it's impossible to guarantee that your luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have a layover.

Airports have a system to handle luggage. Airlines require passengers to check in early to allow time for baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. They also have minimum connecting times, which are the shortest time it takes to transfer between flights. However, delays and security checks can cause problems, and human error or accidents can also occur. Large airports, known as hubs, can be particularly prone to issues due to the high volume of luggage.

It's a good idea to choose direct flights whenever possible and check in early. If you need to change planes, try to fly with the same airline and allow extra time for connections. Make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, and include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, report the issue to the airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who specializes in taking pictures of kingfishers. These birds are known for their bright blue-green feathers and are often found near streams and rivers, where they feed on fish. When the kingfisher flies, it moves quickly and precisely, leaving a lasting impression on the observer.

Charlie James has been fascinated by kingfishers since he was young. He can't quite explain why, but he feels a deep connection to these birds. In fact, he loves them so much that he has dedicated his career to photographing them. Kingfishers have a special place in many cultures, including Greek mythology, where they are associated with the moon and the sun.

Interestingly, kingfishers don't actually have blue feathers. Instead, the way their feathers are structured allows them to reflect blue light, giving them their distinctive color. This is why they can appear to change color depending on the angle of the light.

As a wildlife photographer, Charlie James has spent many hours waiting patiently for kingfishers to appear. He has even built his own hideouts, such as an old blanket, to get up close and personal with the birds. It took him four years to get his first good picture, but it was worth it. Today, Charlie James is a renowned wildlife photographer, and he continues to pursue his passion for kingfishers.

In the future, Charlie would like to make a film about kingfishers that features beautiful, wordless images. He is drawn to the simple, yet powerful, way that kingfishers communicate through their colors and movements. Despite his success as a photographer, Charlie knows that there is still much more to his relationship with kingfishers that he can express through his work.<|eot_id|>

Five women share their experiences of setting up a business in the countryside. They all chose to leave the city for a better work-life balance and more freedom.

Maggy Sasanow is a designer who works from home, creating greetings cards. She trained in art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there wasn't much work available in the countryside. Delia Turner's curtain-making business has had its ups and downs. She started the business eight years ago and it grew quickly, but then the economy declined and she had to lay off her employees. She now works from home with the help of her husband and a few part-time workers. She has to be flexible and adapt to changing circumstances.

Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside for financial reasons and to be closer to nature. She works long hours, taking calls at odd times of the day, and has to discipline herself to stay focused. Her business is international, with clients in Australia, the Far East, and North America.

Meg Rivers started a cakes-by-post business from her home and then expanded to a shop. She is passionate about healthy eating and makes high-quality cakes using good ingredients. She has built a team of six employees and has a turnover of £250,000 per year. Her biggest challenge has been managing the financial side of the business.

John has since become a full-time instrument maker and makes up to 12 violins a year. He even sold one to a famous American musician, which was a great achievement.

Both Paul and Huw started playing music at a young age. Paul began with the piano, and then switched to the cello. Huw, on the other hand, started with the piano and later discovered his own passion for the cello.

The family is very supportive of each other's musical endeavors. Paul has won several awards, including the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. He was also appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the age of 20. Huw is now a pianist and composer, and his string quartet is set to be performed at the Wigmore Hall.

The family is proud of each other's achievements, and John is happy to see his sons pursuing their musical passions. However, it can be challenging for John and Hetty to keep track of their sons' busy schedules, with Paul performing at the Cheltenham Festival and Huw's string quartet receiving its London premiere on the same night.

SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS: HELPING CHILDREN WITH EXCEPTIONAL MUSICAL TALENT

Some children show exceptional musical ability, but it can be difficult for parents to know how to help them develop their talent. Many parents may not recognize their child's need until they start to show signs of frustration. This can lead to behavior problems. Schools that focus on academic subjects may not be the best place for musically gifted children, as they may not have the resources or expertise to support their development.

Specialist music schools in Britain offer a supportive environment where children aged 7-18 can develop their musical skills with the guidance of professional musicians. These schools provide a unique environment where children can spend a significant amount of time practicing music, receiving individual lessons, and participating in orchestras, chamber groups, and theory classes. They also have private practice rooms and a limited academic program that focuses on essential subjects like English, math, science, and languages.

The schools are independent and have a high teacher-to-student ratio, with small class sizes. Most students are boarders, living at the school full-time. This allows them to focus on their music and be surrounded by like-minded peers.

However, there are some disadvantages. The schools are expensive, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 per year for boarders. Additionally, some parents may not want to send their children to boarding school at a young age. The directors of the schools express concerns about admitting children as young as 7 to such an intense environment.

While setting musically gifted children apart from their peers can cause stress, the schools monitor individual progress and offer support when needed. Some former students feel that they benefited from the high-quality music education, but others feel that the limited academic program was a drawback.

For some musically gifted children, it may be better to wait until they are older before considering a specialist education. They may do well in a school with a strong music program or by combining their music training with a normal school routine. However, this option may not be suitable for families living outside of major cities.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

Are you trying to get your story published? If you're wondering where to send it, our expert Margaret Stubbs is here to help. Many readers of this magazine ask us, "I've written a story/book, can you tell me who to send it to?" The first thing you need to know is that you should research the market and find out about publishers, as well as improve your writing skills. To succeed, you need to know the publishing industry. One way to do this is by reading widely and staying up-to-date with new publications. Visit your local library and bookstores to see what's popular and what publishers are looking for. You should also update your knowledge as new publications emerge and editors change jobs.

When you're starting out, you might not be sure what kind of writing you want to do. Let's say you're interested in writing short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories and get hold of some recent issues. Read the types of stories they publish and take note of their target audience. These readers will have different expectations, and editors only want to cater to their needs.

Many writers send me their work, saying, "I've been rejected three times - am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it's unlikely that the work is publishable. Most new writers send their work out too soon, before they're ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success stories often involve years of experience in the publishing industry.

When you finally send your work out, start writing more while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, twenty even. Each one will be better than the last, and you'll start to see yourself as a writer. Don't be afraid to improve your work instead of giving up. I also advise not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding. To advance your writing career, consider taking a creative writing course or joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and make writing a daily habit.<|eot_id|>

On the last day of a difficult year, I was waiting for my train at Baltimore station. There were more people than I expected, and the usual feeling of cleanliness and brightness was gone. Elderly couples were sitting on the benches, and college students were scattered around with their bags. A well-dressed man was walking around, talking to strangers. He asked a woman if she was going to Philadelphia, and then came over to a girl with blonde hair who was standing near me. I had been thinking I might talk to her too. The man asked her if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said she was going to New York. He didn't ask me, and instead went to ask an old lady and then a couple with matching luggage. I was curious about him, so I watched him.

He seemed stressed and was asking people if they were going to Philadelphia. One woman told him she was going to Wilmington, and he didn't say anything. He then asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia, and she said yes. He asked her for a favour, but she seemed hesitant. I was about to leave, but the train announcement came on, and people started moving towards the gate. The man told the woman that his daughter was leaving for a study year abroad and had forgotten her passport. He had left her at the station and was looking for someone to bring her the passport. The woman was sympathetic, but I thought it was an unusual story. The man said his wife was in a wheelchair, which seemed like an excuse. I thought it was a suspicious story, especially because he was carrying a padded envelope that looked like it was stapled shut.

I've told him to focus on one thing at a time and not spread himself too thin.

Gary went to catering college at 17 and quickly stood out among his peers. He's now a successful TV chef, and I'm extremely proud of him. I've always told him that success requires hard work, and he's taken that advice to heart. I'm happy that he's listened to me and made the most of the opportunities he's been given.

Here is the simplified text for a C1 learner:

People love dolphins, but unfortunately, their situation is very concerning. According to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their numbers are declining. Dolphins are highly intelligent and sensitive to human emotions, which is why they have a special place in our hearts. We often see them in films, TV shows, and at seaside attractions, but these portrayals hide the reality of their lives in polluted and overfished oceans.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. Despite their popularity, dolphins are not well protected by law and are not given the care they need. There are 40 different types of dolphins worldwide, and in northern Europe, the most common ones are the striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoise.

The striped and common dolphins live far out at sea and are rarely seen. The bottlenose and harbour porpoises, on the other hand, used to be common near European coastlines. However, their numbers have declined, and those that remain are showing signs of stress. It's difficult to determine the exact reasons for this decline, but overfishing, which is threatening the world's fish stocks, is a major factor.

Overfishing not only harms fish but also affects porpoises and dolphins, as they need to find food quickly and may not survive if fish are removed from their usual areas. They are also at risk of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which can be invisible to them. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on French and Cornish beaches, showing signs of having been caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also be affected by waste and pollutants in the sea, such as pesticides, which can build up in their bodies and be passed on to their young. In fact, there is already a recorded case of a young dolphin being poisoned by its mother's milk. Noise pollution from human activities like shipping and oil drilling is another threat to dolphins, as it can disturb them in ways we don't yet fully understand.

"Exercise is essential for our overall well-being. It's a great way to maintain a balance in our busy lives, where everything seems to be moving fast and getting more chaotic. There are many reasons why exercise is beneficial, and few reasons not to do it. Regular exercise can improve our physical appearance, boost our mood, and even help us sleep better. It can also reduce stress and alleviate certain medical conditions.

There are many types of exercise we can do, such as aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, and weightlifting. However, it's essential to start slowly and carefully to avoid injuries. It's also important to listen to your body and consult a doctor if you're unsure what's best for you.

Good posture is crucial for our overall well-being. It not only affects how we look but also how we feel. Practicing good posture can make us feel more energetic and reduce the risk of minor health complaints. To improve our posture, we can imagine a helium balloon attached to the top of our head, lifting us up and straightening our spine.

Stretching is also an important part of our exercise routine. It improves flexibility, makes movements easier, and helps prevent injuries. By incorporating stretching into our routine, we can maintain a more flexible and fitter body. The best exercise routine involves a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

Remember, exercise is not just about physical appearance; it's about feeling good, both physically and mentally. By incorporating exercise into our daily routine, we can improve our overall well-being and live a healthier, happier life."<|eot_id|>
